moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 e6 3. e3 c5 4. c4: I have to confess that I am at loss, since I nevery play this kind of game (very usual) with white pieces. So I was improvising, trying not to fall in stupid tricks.
moves.4... cxd4 5. exd4 Bb4+: This is much more I use to play! In my beloved Budapes, though, I have no central pawns, with lots of useful lines for attack.
moves.6. Nc3 Ne4: Even better. I make pressure on white, and force him into my game.
moves.7. Bd2: I can choose: NxB is ok if I want to save my own dsb, but I can also exchange it for the N in order to clear some ways.
moves.7... d5: This could have been a mistake. Now white can take NxN, and I almost lose a piece. dxN (if BxN+, NxB and I am a piece under!), BxB, exNe3, Qxe3.
moves.8. cxd5: My opponent chooses to free the way for his lsb to b5.
moves.8... exd5 9. Ne5: Well played, since it makes Bb5+ more dangerous.
moves.9... Bxc3: I saw a way to revert the possible pressure. White could have tried Nxf7, with known and uncertain results. I'll threat first.
moves.10. Bxc3 Qf6: White is forced to care for f2, and if he does properly, the game will come out even enough to be long and drawn.
moves.11. f3: ?? but if he helps me like this, he makes me think I know how to play this game, which is not true.
moves.11... Qh4+ 12. Ke2: If g3, Nxg3, of course. Not necessarily winning, but nice to play. Now the obvious one was Ng3+, winning the exchange. But... what about...
moves.12... Qf2+ 13. Kd3: Ok, now I knew I could have just trapped myself into a dead way, but I just needed one more attacker to get mate. Which is it, and which is the only right way to bring it in? Please, stop the video... :-D
moves.13... b6: I think there is nothing white can do... it was a lucky move, but I am proud of have found it, and also its elegance.
moves.14. fxe4 Ba6+ 15. Nc4 Bxc4#: If I wanted to create such a position for a tactic excercise, I could have lost half of my life! :-) Thanks to my opp!
